data.title: Index Bi
data.text:
Rulers

Index Bi-Bn

Biancheri

Biancheri, Franck (b. May 2, 1960), finance and economy minister (2000-06) and foreign minister (2008-11) of Monaco.

Bianchi, Leonardo (b. April 5, 1848, San Bartolomeo in Galdo, Two Sicilies [now in Benevento province, Italy] - d. Feb. 13, 1927, Naples, Italy), Italian politician. Also known as a psychiatrist and neuropathologist, he was minister of education (1905) and a minister without portfolio (1916-17).

Bianchi, Michele (b. July 22, 1883, Belmonte Calabro, Cosenza province, Italy - d. Feb. 3, 1930, Rome, Italy), Italian politician. He was secretary of the National Fascist Party (1921-22) and minister of public works (1929-30).

Bianchi Gundián, Manuel (b. Jan. 14, 1895, Santiago, Chile - d. Dec. 16, 1982, Santiago), foreign minister of Chile (1940-41). He was also chargé d'affaires in Brazil (1925) and the Dominican Republic (1927), minister to Panama and Cuba (1927-28) and Bolivia (1929-33), and ambassador to Mexico (1934-39) and the United Kingdom (1941-52).

E. Bianco

Biaou

Bianco, Enzo (b. Feb. 24, 1951, Aidone, Enna province, Italy), interior minister of Italy (1999-2001). He was also mayor of Catania (1988-89, 1993-2000, 2013-18).

Bianco, José de Abreu (b. June 15, 1944, Apucarana, Paraná, Brazil), governor of Rondônia (1999-2003). He was also mayor of Ji-Paraná (1989-93, 2005-13).

Biang, Michel Xavier, Gabonese diplomat. He has been ambassador to Congo (Kinshasa), Uganda, Rwanda, and Burundi (2015-17) and permanent representative to the United Nations (2017- ).

Biaou, Rogatien (b. May 19, 1952, Niamey, Niger), foreign minister of Benin (2003-06). He was dismissed on Feb. 15, 2006, in connection with an illicit sale of part of the estate of the embassy of Benin in Washington. While Biaou was the secretary-general of the foreign ministry (2000-03), Thomas Guédégbé, a diplomat at the Washington embassy, allegedly sold the land. Biaou was arrested on February 20 but released on February 22.

Biasutti, Adriano (Sante) (b. Oct. 14, 1941, Palazzolo dello Stella [now in Friuli-Venezia Giulia], Italy - d. Jan. 29, 2010, Udine, Italy), president of Friuli-Venezia Giulia (1984-91).

Biazzi, Ricardo (Roberto) (b. March 11, 1950, San Francisco, Córdoba province, Argentina), education minister of Argentina (2001).

Bibalou Bounda, Marianne Odette, Gabonese diplomat. She has been chargé d'affaires in Egypt (1995) and at the United Nations (2014-15) and ambassador to Germany (2019- ).

Bibb, George M(ortimer) (b. Oct. 30, 1776, Prince Edward county, Va. - d. April 14, 1859, Georgetown [now part of Washington], D.C.), U.S. treasury secretary (1844-45); son-in-law of Charles Scott.

Bibb, Thomas (b. April 7, 1783, Amelia county, Va. - d. Sept. 20, 1839, Limestone county, Ala.), governor of Alabama (1820-21); brother of William W. Bibb.

Bibb, William W(yatt) (b. Oct. 2, 1781, Amelia county, Va. - d. [after fall from horse] July 10, 1820, Elmore county, Ala.), governor of Alabama (1817-20).

Bibikov, Aleksandr (Aleksandrovich) (b. Jan. 18 [Jan. 7, O.S.], 1765 - d. Aug. 1, 1822), Russian diplomat. He was minister to Portugal (1799), Saxony (1799-1800), and Naples (1808-10).

Bibikov, Dmitry (Gavrilovich) (b. March 29 [March 18, O.S.], 1791 - d. March 6 [Feb. 22, O.S.], 1870, St. Petersburg, Russia), interior minister of Russia (1852-55); cousin of Aleksandr Bibikov; son-in-law of Sergey Kushnikov; brother-in-law of Matvey (Matveyevich) Muromtsev. He was also military governor of Kiev and governor-general of Podolia and Volyn (1838-52).

Bibikov, Illarion (Mikhailovich) (b. 1793 - d. Feb. 14 [Feb. 2, O.S.], 1860), governor of Nizhny Novgorod (1829-31), Kaluga (1831-37), and Saratov (1837-39); cousin of Nikolay Bibikov.

Bibikov, Ilya (Bogdanovich) (d. March 9 [Feb. 25, O.S.], 1805), governor of Kazan (1779-83) and Novgorod-Seversky (1784-92).

Bibikov, Ilya (Gavrilovich) (b. Aug. 31 [Aug. 20, O.S.], 1794 - d. April 18 [April 6, O.S.], 1867), governor-general of Vilna, Kovno, and Grodno (1850-55); brother of Dmitry Bibikov; cousin of Aleksandr Bibikov.

Bibikov, Mikhail (Mikhailovich) (b. June 27 [June 15, O.S.], 1849, Vsekhsvyatskoye village, Moscow province, Russia - d. Jan. 24 [Jan. 11, O.S.], 1918, Kislovodsk, Stavropol province, Russia), governor of Voronezh (1906-09); grandson of Illarion Bibikov.

Bibikov, Nikolay (Petrovich) (b. c. 1808 - d. af. 1861), governor of Simbirsk (1852-56) and Kursk (1856-61).

Bibilov

Bibilov, Anatoly (Ilich) (b. Feb. 6, 1970, Tskhinvali, South Ossetian autonomous oblast, Georgian S.S.R.), president of South Ossetia (2017-22). Also a candidate in the invalidated 2011 presidential election, he was minister for civil defense and emergencies (2008-14) and speaker of parliament (2014-17).

Bicakcic

Bicakcic, Edhem (b. Jan. 17, 1952, Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina), prime minister of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (1996-2001). He was sacked as chief of the state power firm Elektroprivreda BiH by International High Representative Wolfgang Petritsch in February 2001 because as prime minister he had "abused the powers vested in his office to redirect public revenues through a complex and corrupt system of financial diversions, with large sums of money ending in the coffers of the Party of Democratic Action."

Biçaku, Ibrahim Bej (b. Sept. 10, 1905, Elbasan, Ottoman Empire [now in Albania] - d. Jan. 4, 1977, Elbasan), chairman of the Provisional Executive Committee (1943) and prime minister, foreign minister, and interior minister (1944) of Albania. After his capture by Communist forces in 1944, he was imprisoned until 1962.

Bicalho, Maurício Chagas (b. March 19, 1913, Oliveira, Minas Gerais, Brazil - d. Dec. 14, 1999, Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais), acting finance minister of Brazil (intermittently 1959-60). He was also president of the Bank of Brazil (1959-60).

Bicamumpaka, Jérôme(-Clément) (b. 1957, Ruhondo commune, Ruhengeri prefecture, Rwanda), foreign minister of Rwanda (1994). Arrested in Cameroon in 1999, he was charged with genocide and tried by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda but fully acquitted in 2011.

Bicheldey, Kaadyr-ool (Alekseyevich) (b. Jan. 2, 1950), chairman of the Supreme Council of Tuva (1991-92).

Bickett, Thomas W(alter) (b. Feb. 28, 1869, Monroe, N.C. - d. Dec. 27, 1921, Raleigh, N.C.), governor of North Carolina (1917-21).

Bicoumat, Germain (b. April 20, 1906, Diosso, near Pointe-Noire, Middle Congo [now Congo (Brazzaville)] - d. 1993), interior minister of Congo (Brazzaville) (1963-65). He was also minister of public works (1961-62) and information (1963) and ambassador to East Germany (1966-69) and West Germany (1969-70).

Bicudo, Hélio Pereira (b. July 5, 1922, Moji das Cruzes, São Paulo, Brazil - d. July 31, 2018, São Paulo, Brazil), acting finance minister of Brazil (1963).

Bidal

Bidal, René (b. Jan. 18, 1960, Béziers, Hérault, France), high commissioner of French Polynesia (2016-19). He was also prefect of the French départements of Hautes-Pyrénées (2010-11), Pyrénées-Orientales (2011-14), Eure (2014-16), and Maine-et-Loire (2019-20).

Bidault

Bidault, Georges (Augustin) (b. Oct. 5, 1899, Moulins, Allier, France - d. Jan. 27, 1983, Cambo-les-Bains, Pyrénées-Atlantiques), prime minister of France (1946, 1949-50). In 1941 he joined the National Council of Resistance, of which he became president in 1943 after the death of Jean Moulin. In 1944 he was a founder of the Mouvement Républicain Populaire, a Christian-Democratic party. As foreign minister (1944-46) in Charles de Gaulle's provisional government, Bidault signed the Franco-Soviet alliance in December 1944 and in the following year signed the UN Charter. After heading the provisional government in 1946, he was again foreign minister in 1947-48, prime minister in 1949-50, defense minister in 1951-52, and once more foreign minister in 1953-54. With the return of de Gaulle to power (1958), Bidault broke with his wartime friend over the issue of Algerian independence and founded a new, right-wing Christian-Democratic Party. When de Gaulle put down a coup and negotiated Algerian independence in 1961, Bidault, still a member of the National Assembly, created a national council of resistance that advocated terrorism in France and Algeria to prevent Algerian independence, and went underground, claiming the illegality of de Gaulle's government. Charged with conspiracy and stripped of his parliamentary immunity from arrest, he fled France in 1962, living in neighbouring countries and Brazil (1963-67). In 1968, after an amnesty declared by de Gaulle for all those accused of crimes against the state during the Algerian war, Bidault returned to France and founded the right-wing Mouvement pour la justice et la liberté, but this failed to make a mark in French politics. He became honorary president of the Christian-Democratic Party in 1977.

Biddle, Charles (b. Dec. 24, 1745, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania - d. April 4, 1821, Philadelphia), acting president of the Supreme Executive Council of Pennsylvania (1785).

Biddle, Francis (Beverley) (b. May 9, 1886, Paris, France - d. Oct. 4, 1968, Hyannis, Mass.), U.S. solicitor general (1940-41) and attorney general (1941-45).

Biddle, Livingston L(udlow), Jr. (b. May 26, 1918, Bryn Mawr, Pa. - d. May 3, 2002, Washington, D.C.), chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts (1977-81).

Biddulph, John (b. July 25, 1840 - d. Dec. 31, 1921, Ham Common, Surrey [now part of London], England), acting chief commissioner of Baluchistan (1891).

Biddulph, Sir Robert (b. Aug. 26, 1835, London, England - d. Nov. 18, 1918, London), high commissioner of Cyprus (1879-86) and governor of Gibraltar (1893-1900); knighted 1880.

Biden

Biden, Joe, byname of Joseph Robinette Biden, Jr. (b. Nov. 20, 1942, Scranton, Pa.), vice president (2009-17) and president (2021- ) of the United States. The Democrat from Delaware was first elected to the Senate in 1972. He unsuccessfully ran for the 1988 and 2008 Democratic presidential nominations. In 2008 he became Democratic candidate Barack Obama's running mate. Biden, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, brought years of experience that served to help counter Republican arguments that an Obama administration would be inexperienced on foreign policy. With the success of the ticket, he became vice-president-elect in November. In office, he maintained his reputation of being prone to verbal gaffes. In April 2019 he entered the race for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination. He fared poorly in the first three contests, and his gaffes only became more serious, but when he won in South Carolina - his first win in any of his presidential runs - the Democratic establishment rallied around him as the candidate to stop progressive insurgent Bernie Sanders; at Super Tuesday (March 3, 2020), he took over the lead from Sanders. When Sanders dropped out of the race in April 2020, Biden emerged as the presumptive nominee. In June he secured a majority of delegates. In August he named Kamala Harris as his running mate and was officially nominated. It was clear that the election would be more than anything a referendum on Pres. Donald Trump, Biden being essentially a placeholder for a return to normalcy, without provoking excitement for any policy proposals of his own. He conducted a low-key campaign, explained - or conveniently excused - by the COVID-19 pandemic, and stayed behind expectations in the November election, while still defeating Trump 51%-47% and flipping five states to win 306 electoral votes. His proclaimed "battle for the soul of the nation" had not been won as decisively as to put an immediate end to the cult of Trump, who refused to concede and rallied his forces behind the fiction of a "stolen" election. On taking office, Biden, at 78, not only obliterated the record that had just been set by Trump as the oldest person to become president, but also immediately became the oldest president in office at any time (i.e., older than Ronald Reagan on leaving office). In 2021 he effected the final withdrawal from Afghanistan, ending a 20-year intervention whose futility was proved by an immediate Taliban takeover. His support of Israel's genocidal rampage in Gaza from 2023 not just led to a near-wipeout of his previously strong support among Muslim Americans, but also to a steep drop in support among young people; students protested across the country, but their encampments were ultimately shut down by police. This already made his electoral prospects precarious when the 2024 election shaped up to be a rematch of 2020. Then his poor performance in a debate with Trump in June 2024 brought the issue of his age to the centre of discussion and led to increasing calls for his withdrawal from the race. He submitted to the pressure in July.

Bidouzo, Barnabé (b. June 11, 1937, Covè, Dahomey [now Benin]), finance minister of Benin (1987-88).

Bidwell

Bidwell, John (b. Aug. 5, 1819, Chautauqua county, N.Y. - d. April 4, 1900, Chico, Calif.), U.S. politician. Reluctant to join the Bear Flag revolt of Americans in California against Mexico, he nonetheless helped draw up the Bear Flag Republic's resolution of independence in July 1846. He attained the rank of major while participating in the Mexican War; he marched to Monterey (California) with Col. John C. Frémont, served as civil magistrate in Los Angeles, and finally assisted Commodore Robert F. Stockton in the recapture of Los Angeles in 1847. He later served in the California senate in 1849, supervised the census of California in 1850 and again in 1860, and was a delegate to the Democratic Party national convention of 1860. With the advent of the Civil War, Bidwell, a staunch Unionist, became a supporter of Abraham Lincoln. He was appointed brigadier general of the California Militia in 1863 and was a delegate to the Republican national convention of 1864. Elected to the House of Representatives in 1864, he declined renomination in order to run for governor of California on the Republican ticket in 1867; his bid was unsuccessful, as were his two others, one in 1875 on the Anti-Monopoly ticket and another in 1890 as a candidate of the Prohibition Party, which nominated him for president in 1892. He received 2.5% of the vote, the best result ever for a Prohibition Party candidate.

Biebrich Torres, Carlos Armando (b. Nov. 19, 1939, Sahuaripa, Sonora, Mexico - d. Jan. 14, 2021, Hermosillo, Sonora), governor of Sonora (1973-75).

Biedenkopf

Bielecki

Biedenkopf, Kurt (Hans) (b. Jan. 28, 1930, Ludwigshafen, Bayern [now in Rheinland-Pfalz], Germany - d. Aug. 12, 2021, Dresden, Sachsen, Germany), minister-president of Sachsen (1990-2002). He was also general secretary of the Christian Democratic Union of Germany (1973-77).

Biegman, Nicolaas Hendrik (b. Sept. 23, 1936, Apeldoorn, Netherlands), Dutch diplomat. He was ambassador to Egypt (1984-88) and permanent representative to the United Nations (1992-97).

Bielecki, Jan Krzysztof (b. May 3, 1951, Bydgoszcz, Poland), prime minister of Poland (1991).

Bielich Flores, (Pedro Antonio) Ismael (b. June 13, 1899, Lima, Peru - d. Dec. 2, 1966, Lima), justice and labour minister of Peru (1945-47).

Bielka-Karltreu, Erich (b. May 12, 1908, Vienna, Austria - d. Sept. 1, 1992, Vienna), foreign minister of Austria (1974-76). He was also ambassador to Turkey (1952-58), Switzerland (1968-72), and France (1972-74).

Bielke, Carl Gustaf greve (b. July 12, 1683, Stockholm, Sweden - d. Feb. 11, 1754, Stockholm), governor of Västernorrland (1727-39); son of Nils greve Bielke.

Bielke, Nils greve (b. Feb. 7, 1644, Stockholm, Sweden - d. Nov. 26, 1716, Lena socken, Uppsala, Sweden), Swedish governor-general of Estonia (1687) and Pomerania (1687-98). He was also ambassador to France (1679-82). He was made greve (count) in 1687.

Bielke, Nils Adam greve (b. Jan. 30, 1724, Göteborg, Sweden - d. June 20, 1792, Vist socken [now part of Linköping municipality], Östergötland, Sweden), governor of Södermanland (1761-69); nephew of Carl Gustaf greve Bielke; grandson of Nils greve Bielke.

Bielke, Ture Stensson friherre (b. 1655 - d. Dec. 20, 1717), governor of Stockholm (1714-17).

Bielsa (Caldera), Rafael (Antonio) (b. Feb. 15, 1953, Rosario, Argentina), foreign minister of Argentina (2003-05). He has also been ambassador to Chile (2020- ).

Bienert

Bienert, Richard (b. Sept. 5, 1881, Prague, Austria [now in Czech Republic] - d. Feb. 3, 1949, Prague, Czechoslovakia [now in Czech Republic]), interior minister (1942-45) and prime minister (1945) of the Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia. He was Landespräsident of Bohemia in 1939-42.

Bienerth-Schmerling, Richard (Joseph Anton Karl) Graf von (count of), until 1915 Richard Freiherr (baron) von Bienerth (b. March 2, 1863, Verona, Austria [now in Italy] - d. June 3, 1918, Vienna, Austria), interior minister (1906-08) and prime minister (1908-11) of Austria and Statthalter of Niederösterreich (1911-15); grandson of Anton Ritter von Schmerling. He was also minister of education (1905-06).

Bienkowska, Elzbieta (Ewa), née Moycho (b. Feb. 4, 1964, Katowice, Poland), a deputy prime minister of Poland (2013-14). She was also minister of regional development (2007-13) and infrastructure and development (2013-14) and EU commissioner for internal market, industry, entrepreneurship, and small and medium-sized enterprises (2014-19).

Bienvenu-Martin, Jean-Baptiste (b. July 22, 1847, Saint-Bris-le-Vineux, Yonne, France - d. Dec. 10, 1943, Saint-Bris-le-Vineux), justice minister of France (1913-14, 1914). He was also minister of public instruction, fine arts, and worship (1905-06) and labour and social security (1914-15).

Bienville

Bienville, Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, sieur de (baptized Feb. 23, 1680, Montreal, New France [now in Canada] - d. March 7, 1767, Paris, France), governor of Louisiana (1701-12, 1718-24, 1733-43). Entering the French navy at age 12, he served as midshipman in the last expedition of his noted elder brother, Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville, into the Hudson Bay region (1697) during King William's War (War of the Grand Alliance). When the conflict with England ended, he accompanied his brother on a colonizing expedition to the mouth of the Mississippi River. A settlement was founded near the area of modern Biloxi in early 1699, and he was made second in command of the colony when his brother departed in the spring. When the colony's leader, Sauvole, died in 1701, Bienville was commissioned as commandant. He transferred the colony to Mobile Bay in 1702 and founded Mobile in 1710. In 1712 he was replaced by Antoine de Lamothe Cadillac, under whom he served as deputy for three years. In 1718, Bienville regained the governor's post. At that time he founded the settlement of New Orleans on the Mississippi River, and four years later he made that city the new capital of the colony. In 1719 he twice captured Pensacola from the Spanish. Fearing insurrections of black slaves, he instituted a "Code Noir" regulating their conduct (1724). When the Company of the Indies, which had been financing Louisiana, became unable to continue its support, Bienville's enemies succeeded in having him recalled to France. Upon Louisiana's subsequent decline, however, he was asked to return as governor in 1733. His final term was marked by indecisive expeditions against the Natchez and Chickasaw Indians. He voluntarily resigned the governorship in May 1743 and retired to Paris.

Bierlein

Bierlein, Brigitte (b. June 25, 1949, Vienna, Austria - d. June 3, 2024), chancellor of Austria (2019-20). She was also president of the Constitutional Court (2018-19).

Biernacki, Marek (b. April 28, 1959, Sopot, Poland), interior minister (1999-2001) and justice minister (2013-14) of Poland.

Bierring, Ole (b. Nov. 9, 1926, Copenhagen, Denmark - d. March 19, 2011), Danish diplomat. He was ambassador to France (1980-84) and permanent representative to the United Nations (1984-88).

Bierut

Bierut, Boleslaw, original surname Biernacki (b. April 18, 1892, Rury Jezuickie, near Lublin, Poland - d. March 12, 1956, Moscow, Russian S.F.S.R.), leader of the Polish United Workers' Party (1948-56), head of state (1944-52), and premier (1952-54). He joined the Polish Communist Party in 1918 and became an underground organizer in Poland as well as in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, and Austria. Arrested and imprisoned several times in the 1920s and '30s for his activities in Poland, he went to Russia after his release in 1938 and remained there during most of World War II. He returned to Poland at the end of 1943 and with Wladyslaw Gomulka and others formed the Polish National Council. He became provisional head of the Polish republic in 1944, even before the last Germans were driven from the country, and in 1947 was elected to a seven-year term as president. By that time Bierut and his fellow Communists, with the backing of Stalin and the Soviet army, had disposed of all effective opposition, and he began his efforts to Sovietize all aspects of Polish life. Always a loyal follower of party directives from Moscow, he was instrumental in the September 1948 deposition as secretary-general of the Polish Workers' Party of Gomulka, who had attempted to bend the Soviet party line to Polish circumstances. Bierut replaced him and reorganized the party to form the Polish United Workers' Party (PZPR) in December 1948, becoming chairman of its Central Committee. In 1952, when the president's duties were taken over by a State Council, he became premier, but he resigned that post also in 1954, when he became secretary-general of the PZPR. After attending the Soviet Communist Party's 20th Congress in Moscow, at which Nikita Khrushchev presented his famous "Crimes of the Stalin Era" report, he fell ill and died.

Biesèrt, (Johan) Elof (b. Sept. 30, 1862, Töcksmark socken, Värmland, Sweden - d. July 14, 1928), finance minister of Sweden (1905-06).

Biesheuvel

Biesheuvel, Barend (Willem) (b. April 5, 1920, Haarlemmerliede, Noord-Holland, Netherlands - d. April 29, 2001, Haarlem, Noord-Holland), prime minister of the Netherlands (1971-73). He was also leader of the Anti-Revolutionary Party (1963-73) and a deputy prime minister and minister of agriculture and fisheries (1963-67).

Bieter, David H(arold) (b. Nov. 1, 1959, Boise, Idaho), mayor of Boise (2004-20).

Biffot, Laurent (Marie) (b. Feb. 20, 1925, Nkovié, Gabon - d. Jan. 31, 2015, Paris, France), Gabonese diplomat. He was permanent representative to the United Nations (1987-88) and ambassador to Ethiopia (1989-90).

Bigelow, Hobart B(aldwin) (b. May 16, 1834, North Haven, Conn. - d. Oct. 12, 1891, New Haven, Conn.), governor of Connecticut (1881-83).

Biget, Jacques (b. April 19, 1922, Landrecies, Nord, France - d. May 15, 1978, Saint-Vallier-de-Thiey, Alpes-Maritimes, France), interior minister of Monaco (1965-67).

Bigger, Samuel (b. March 20, 1802, Warren county, Ohio - d. Sept. 9, 1846, Fort Wayne, Ind.), governor of Indiana (1840-43).

Biggs, Benjamin T(homas) (b. Oct. 1, 1821, Pencader Hundred, Newcastle county, Del. - d. Dec. 25, 1893, Middletown, Del.), governor of Delaware (1887-91).

Bigi, Federico (b. March 21, 1920, Reggio Emilia, Italy - d. April 24, 1996, San Marino), member of the Provisional Government (1957) and secretary of state for foreign and political affairs (1957-72) of San Marino.

Bigirwenkya, Z(erubaberi) H(osea) K(wamya) (b. May 24, 1927, Masindi, Bunyoro district, Uganda - d. Dec. 26, 1992), secretary-general of the East African Community (1968-71).

Bigler, John (b. Jan. 8, 1805, near Carlisle, Pa. - d. Nov. 29, 1871, Sacramento, Calif.), governor of California (1852-56). He was also U.S. minister to Chile (1857-61).

Bigler, William (b. Jan. 1, 1814, Shermansburg, Pa. - d. Aug. 9, 1880, Clearfield, Pa.), governor of Pennsylvania (1852-55); brother of John Bigler.

Bignon, Louis (Pierre Édouard), baron (b. Jan. 3, 1771, Guerbaville, near Meilleraye [now in Seine-Maritime département], France - d. Jan. 5, 1841, Paris, France), foreign minister of France (1815, 1830). He was also minister to Baden (1808-10), minister of public instruction (1830), and minister without portfolio (1830). He was created baron in 1808.

Bignone

Bignone (Ramayón), Reynaldo (Benito Antonio) (b. Jan. 21, 1928, Morón, Buenos Aires province, Argentina - d. March 7, 2018, Buenos Aires, Argentina), president of Argentina (1982-83). In April 2010 he was convicted and sentenced to 25 years in prison for kidnappings, torture, and murders during 1976-78, when he was a commander at the Campo Mayo army base. In April 2011 he was sentenced to life in prison for further crimes against humanity. He received further sentences of 15 years in December 2011, 15 years in July 2012, and 20 years in May 2016.

Bigvava, Odissey (Mikhailovich) (b. Jan. 19, 1977, Sukhumi, Abkhaz A.S.S.R., Georgian S.S.R.), acting foreign minister of Abkhazia (2024- ).

Biha, Léopold, byname of Prince Léopold Bihumugani (b. 1919 - buried March 2, 2003), prime minister of Burundi (1965-66).

Bihourd, (Paul Louis) Georges (b. March 22, 1846, Paris, France - d. Aug. 29, 1914, Paris), resident-general of Annam-Tonkin (1887). He was also prefect of the French départements of Aube (1877-79), Hérault (1879-80), Pas-de-Calais (1880-83), and Meurthe-et-Moselle (1883-85) and French minister to Portugal (1890-95) and the Netherlands (1895-1900) and ambassador to Switzerland (1900-02) and Germany (1902-07).

Bihute, Donatien (b. Oct. 22, 1940, Rugombo, Burundi), finance minister of Burundi (1966-67). He was also ambassador to Zaire (1972-74) and minister of planning (1978-81).

Biishev, Akhmed (Almukhametovich) (b. Feb. 24 [Feb. 12, O.S.], 1896, Idelbayevo, Orenburg province, Russia - d. [executed] Sept. 27, 1937), chairman of the Council of People's Commissars (1920-21) and executive secretary of the Communist Party committee (1921) of the Bashkir A.S.S.R.

Bijedic, Dzemal (b. April 22, 1917, Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina - d. [plane crash] Jan. 18, 1977, near Sarajevo), premier of Yugoslavia (1971-77). He was also president of the People's Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina (1967-71).

Bijleveld, Ank, byname of Anna Theodora Bernardina Bijleveld-Schouten (b. March 17, 1962, IJsselmuiden, Overijssel, Netherlands), queen's/king's commissioner of Overijssel (2011-17) and defense minister of the Netherlands (2017-21). She was also minister for the General Intelligence and Security Service (2019-20).

Bikenge Musimbi, Jérôme (b. April 12, 1962), acting governor of Maniema (2017-19).

Bilal

Bilandic

Bilal (Messoud), Mohamed Ould (b. Dec. 31, 1963, Rosso, Mauritania), prime minister of Mauritania (2020- ). He was also minister of infrastructure, urban planning, and housing (2007-08).

Bilandic, Michael A(nthony) (b. Feb. 13, 1923, Chicago - d. Jan. 15, 2002, Chicago), mayor of Chicago (1976-79). He became acting mayor after the death of Richard J. Daley in 1976, was elected in 1977, and defeated in the 1979 Democratic primary. He served on the Illinois Supreme Court from 1990 to 2000; he was chief justice in 1994-96.

Bilbao Eguía, Esteban, (from 1961) marqués de Bilbao Eguía (b. Jan. 11, 1879, Bilbao, Spain - d. Sept. 23, 1970, Durango, Vizcaya province, Spain), justice minister of Spain (1939-43). He was also president of the Cortes (1943-65).

Bilbo, Theodore G(ilmore) (b. Oct. 13, 1877, Juniper Grove, near Poplarville, Miss. - d. Aug. 21, 1947, New Orleans, La.), governor of Mississippi (1916-20, 1928-32). He was also a U.S. senator from Mississippi (1935-47).

C. Bildt

Bildt, (Nils Daniel) Carl (b. July 15, 1949, Halmstad, Halland, Sweden), prime minister of Sweden (1991-94); great-great-grandson of Gillis friherre Bildt. He took a precocious interest in politics from an early age. In 1973 he became a political secretary in the Moderate Party and then confidant to its leader, Gösta Bohman. Bildt was elected as a member of the Stockholm city council in 1974, where he served for three years. During the years of non-Socialist rule in Sweden between 1976 and 1982, he played an important role as a policy coordinator behind the scenes. After two years as adviser at the Finance Ministry, he was elected in 1979 to parliament from Stockholm. He served on various committees including the Defense Committee, before replacing Ulf Adelsohn as Moderate Party leader in August 1986. He owed his rapid advance through the party ranks to a ferocious attack launched on him in 1983 by Prime Minister Olof Palme, who alleged that he was a "security risk." He stood up to Palme's offensive and won the admiration of many conservatives. After the defeat of the Social Democrats in the 1991 election, he became Sweden's youngest prime minister in more than 150 years and the first conservative to lead the country since 1928. Heading a four-party centre-right coalition government, he backed NATO membership for neutral Sweden and was in favour of reforming the nation's rigid labour laws. He was the international community's High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1995 to 1997, charged with overall responsibility for implementing the Dayton peace agreement. In May 1999 he was appointed UN special envoy to the Balkans. He was replaced as leader of the Moderate Party by Bo Lundgren in September 1999. In 2006-14 he was foreign minister.

Bin Laden

Bin Laden, Osama (bin Muhammad) (b. March 10, 1957, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia - d. May 2, 2011, Abbottabad, Pakistan), Islamist militant leader. The son of a Saudi construction magnate, he used his millions to buy bulldozers to gouge guerrilla trails in the heart of Afghanistan and to bring in, by his count, thousands of Egyptians, Lebanese, Turks, and others to join their Afghan Muslim brothers in the struggle against the Soviet Union, which invaded Afghanistan to prop up a Communist government in December 1979. After the war, he returned home, but the Saudi government, fearing his brand of militant Islam, expelled him and in April 1994 stripped him of his Saudi citizenship for "irresponsible behaviour." He ventured to Sudan, but because of Western pressure he was forced to leave in mid-1996, returning to Afghanistan, where the Taliban regime gave him shelter. In a series of fatwas (religious edicts) faxed to the outside world from his Afghan hideout, he laid out his case against the U.S.: its soldiers protecting oil in his homeland are desecrating Muslim holy sites with their very presence; its power has emasculated Arab countries, turning them into client states; its friend is Israel. In February 1998, he helped form the World Islamic Front for Jihad Against Jews and Crusaders, a coalition that brought together two Egyptian militant groups, two Pakistani groups, and a Bangladeshi group. His network, referred to from August 1998 as al-Qaeda ("The Base"), was considered responsible for bombings of U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in the latter month and other terrorist acts, and he definitely became the U.S. "public enemy number one" after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks which destroyed the World Trade Center in New York City. The U.S. then overthrew the Taliban in Afghanistan but failed to capture Bin Laden, who escaped to Pakistan where he managed to live in hiding for almost ten years. His compound was finally tracked down by the U.S. and he was shot in a carefully-planned raid by a U.S. military team.

Binaisa

Binaisa, Godfrey L(ukongwa) (b. May 30, 1920, Kampala, Uganda - d. Aug. 5, 2010, Kampala), president of Uganda (1979-80). In October 1959 he founded the Uganda League, one of several parties seeking self-government for the then-British protectorate. His appointment as attorney general followed the April 1962 elections that brought Milton Obote to the premiership and preceded Uganda's independence in October of that year. Binaisa was one of the few prominent Baganda tribal members to oppose the kabaka (king) of Buganda in the latter's resistance to the Obote government, a conflict that ended in the kabaka's defeat in 1966. In 1967 Binaisa broke with Obote over his use of authoritarian tactics and proposals to change the constitution. As a believer in constitutional law Binaisa felt bound to resign from the government. He returned to private legal practice and in 1968 was elected chairman of the Law Development Centre and president of the Uganda Law Society. In 1970 he became a member of the Uganda Judicial Service Commission and two years later was made chairman of the organizing committee of the Commonwealth Lawyers' Conference. Unlike many of Obote's critics, Binaisa was not among those who welcomed Idi Amin's coup in 1971. He was forced into exile and began a law practice in New York City, which he used as a base to campaign against Amin's rule. After the overthrow of General Amin in April 1979, Uganda needed an experienced and impartial leader capable of firmly reestablishing law and order and of binding up the tribal and religious wounds inflicted during years of tyrannical rule. When the first man chosen to take Amin's place as president, Yusufu Lule, proved unequal to this difficult task, he was replaced in June by Binaisa. He returned to Uganda on April 13, 2001, after more than 10 years of self-imposed exile in the United States.

V.C. Bird

Bird, Sir Vere Cornwall (b. Dec. 7, 1910, St. John's, Antigua - d. June 28, 1999, St. John's), prime minister (1981-94), finance minister (1982-84, 1991), and foreign minister (1991) of Antigua and Barbuda. He was a founding member of the Antigua Trades and Labour Union and rose rapidly to become its president (1943-69). In 1945 he ran for the Legislative Council and was easily elected. A defining moment in the history of Antigua and Barbuda is a legendary - some say apocryphal - speech by Bird under a tamarind tree near the village of Bethesda in January 1951. Bird threatened a strike if sugarcane workers were not given a raise. When Alexander Moody-Stuart, the powerful head of the Antigua Sugar Estates, scoffed and asked what the striking workers would eat, Bird replied: "We will eat cockles and the widdy widdy bush. We will drink pond water." The widdy widdy bush is a common weed in Antigua that was part of the diet of slaves. Bird's reply became a permanent part of the lexicon of political oratory in Antigua. Bird did organize the strike and there was no sugar harvest that year. Through encouraging union members to run for public office, he formed the basis for what became the Antigua Labour Party. When universal adult suffrage was introduced in 1951, the union won every seat in the legislature, a feat it repeated until 1967. In 1960 he became the island's first chief minister, retaining office, with the title of premier, when the island achieved associated statehood in 1967. A split within labour lost him his seat in elections in 1971. However, in 1976 he was returned to power and he led the final constitutional negotiations in London in 1980 that brought the two-island state to independence (Nov. 1, 1981). The dominant figure in Antiguan politics for more than 50 years, Bird retired in 1994. He was knighted in 1999.

Birendra

Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva (b. Dec. 28, 1945, Kathmandu, Nepal - d. June 1, 2001, Kathmandu), king of Nepal (1972-2001). Son of Crown Prince (from 1955, King) Mahendra and Crown Princess Indra, Birendra was educated at St. Joseph's College in Darjeeling, India, and at Eton College (1959-64), Tokyo University (1967), and Harvard University (1967-68). He traveled extensively around the world before acceding to the throne on his father's death on Jan. 31, 1972; he was crowned on Feb. 24, 1975. Birendra continued the autocratic tradition of his father, who had dissolved the elected parliament in 1960 and banned political parties in the constitution of 1962; indeed, for a time, Birendra was one of the world's few remaining absolute monarchs. He managed to defend Nepal's independence against encroaching influences by India, China, and the Soviet Union. During his reign Nepal was opened up to extensive tourism. In 1990 a popular pro-democracy movement erupted into bloody riots between police and demonstrators. On April 8 Birendra acceded to the opposition's demand to lift the ban on political parties, and on November 9 he promulgated a new constitution that preserved his status as chief of state but confirmed multiparty democracy, a separation of powers, and the protection of human rights. In 1996 Maoist rebels launched an armed insurgency aimed at replacing the monarchy; they succeeded in gaining control over large areas of the countryside. On May 2, 1969, he married Aishwarya (b. Nov. 7, 1949, Lazimpat, Kathmandu). They had two sons, Dipendra (b. June 27, 1971) and Nirajan (b. Nov. 6, 1978), and one daughter, Shruti (b. Oct. 16, 1976). On June 1, 2001, he was fatally shot along with Aishwarya, Nirajan, Shruti, and other relatives, in a massacre in the royal palace committed by Dipendra.

Biri, Delba, justice minister of Papua New Guinea (1977-78). He was also minister of corrective institutions (1978-80).
